claim: Summer in the Northern Hemisphere begins in June

supporting.text: Astronomically, summer in the Northern Hemisphere begins with the June solstice, which occurs around June 20-22 each year.

attacks.text: Astronomically, summer in the Northern Hemisphere begins with the June solstice, which occurs around June 20-22 each year.
Meteorologically, summer is defined as the months of June, July, and August in the Northern Hemisphere, starting on June 1, not the solstice.
Astronomical definitions are more scientifically precise and universally recognized than meteorological conventions.
Cultural and regional traditions in some countries mark the beginning of summer on different dates, such as May Day or other local festivals.
While cultural traditions vary, they do not override the astronomical definition used in scientific and international contexts.

supporting.text: The June solstice marks the day with the longest period of daylight in the Northern Hemisphere, a key characteristic of summer.

attacks.text: The June solstice marks the day with the longest period of daylight in the Northern Hemisphere, a key characteristic of summer.

Astronomically, summer in the Northern Hemisphere begins with the June solstice, which can occur between June 20-22, not necessarily in early June.
Meteorological summer is defined as June 1 to August 31, which aligns closely with cultural and calendar systems, reinforcing the general recognition of June as the start of summer.
Some cultures, like those in Ireland, traditionally mark the start of summer in May (e.g., Beltane festival), showing regional variation in seasonal definitions.
Modern globalized culture and standardized calendars have largely homogenized the perception of summer starting in June, reducing the relevance of older regional traditions.
